In explaining this commentary, it is broadly divided into four parts: first, a general preface to the title and meaning; second, from paying homage
downward, paying homage and requesting blessings;
third, from about to explain downward, opening the chapters and explaining the text;
fourth, a single verse at the end of the commentary expressing humility, praise, and dedication, because the sutra text has four parts.

If it is divided according to the sequence of introduction, main text, and conclusion, then the first two parts are the introduction, the opening of the chapters is the main text, and the humility and praise are the conclusion, making three parts for the commentary.

Now, the first is a general preface to the title and meaning, which is the preface to the commentary, also called the traces of the teaching. It is roughly divided into four parts, and finely divided into ten sections.
As for the four parts, first, it generally introduces the Dharma realm as the great principle of Buddhist teachings;
second, from splitting open downward, it specifically describes this sutra to express its purport;
third, from therefore the bodhisattvas search for the hidden downward, it celebrates the encounter and inspires beings to arouse the mind of enlightenment;
Fourth, below The title is called Great Expansive, briefly explaining the title to make people know the main points, also in accordance with the four parts of the sutra.
It is said that there are ten detailed sections, in accordance with the endless, first, pointing out the main body;
Second, below splitting open, praising the expounder separately;
Third, below Therefore I, the inconceivable speaker;
Fourth, below Vast wisdom, the all-encompassing manner of speaking;
Fifth, below Although empty and empty, the words encompass the beginning and end;
Sixth, below Its purpose, the profound and subtle purport;
Seventh, below As for, the sudden transcendence of benefits;
Eighth, below Truly, concluding the praise of the vastness;
Ninth, below Looking back, feeling joy at the encounter;
Tenth, below The title is called, briefly explaining the title.
Now, first.
Going and returning without end...only the Dharma realm? The text has five sentences, the meaning contains many implications, and is briefly explained in four meanings:

First, explaining it in terms of the three greatnesses, second, explaining it in terms of the fundamental and derivative, third, clarifying the distinct categories of the Dharma realm, and fourth, comprehensively revealing the purpose of establishing the teaching.
Now, first.
As for explaining it in terms of the three greatnesses, it intends to clarify that the Dharma realm is endowed with the three greatnesses.

The first sentence clarifies function, the next sentence clarifies essence, the next sentence clarifies characteristics, the next sentence integrates and removes, and the last sentence concludes and attributes.
Now, first, it is the going and returning without limit.
Going means to leave,
to arise, and to move.
Returning means to come, to cease, and to be still.
Without limit has two meanings:
First, in terms of vastness and multiplicity, there is no boundary, this is based on the functioning of phenomena;
Second, in terms of transcending boundaries, it is based on the identity of phenomena and the true nature.
What is the going and returning?
In brief, there are three meanings:

First, speaking of it in terms of both delusion and enlightenment, second, speaking of it solely in terms of delusion, and third, speaking of it in terms of returning to the origin and reverting to the source.
Now, first, it means that in delusion about the Dharma realm, one goes to the six destinies, leaving and moving;
When one realizes the Dharma realm and returns to one mind, it is stillness.
All are the functions of the Dharma realm. When deluded, false thoughts arise; when enlightened, false thoughts cease.
However, truth has two meanings:
First, in terms of following conditions.
When deluded, truth follows falsity, so truth ceases and falsity arises;
When enlightened, falsity ceases and returns to truth, so truth arises and falsity ceases.
Second, in terms of immutability.
Delusion, enlightenment, arising, ceasing, coming and going are in turmoil, while the true realm is as still as empty space.
Since the essence is beginningless, it is without an initial limit. When enlightenment ends the beginning and end, it is without a final limit.
Second, only in terms of delusion, there are also two meanings:
First, discussing the past and future vertically, the past is beginningless and the future is endless, without an initial or final limit;
Second, discussing horizontally, deluded thoughts grasping and clinging are vast and boundless.
The above two are both in terms of the vast multitude being limitless.
If in terms of the ultimate limit, delusion has no source of delusion, vertically it has no initial limit;
Since there is no beginning, how can there be an end? Therefore, it transcends the subsequent limit.
The Zhong lun says: What the Great Sage has said, the fundamental limit cannot be obtained.
Saá¹ƒsÄra has no beginning and also no end.
If there is no beginning or end, how can there be a middle?
Therefore, in this, there is no prior, posterior, or simultaneous existence.
Searching horizontally for the deluded mind, it is not within or without, so it also has no limit.
Therefore, Master Yuan said:
Where does the root end ultimately come from? Arising, ceasing, existence, and nonexistence have no limit.
A single hair that enters the realm of movement forms this mountain-toppling momentum.
Deluded appearances, once mutually transmitted, touch principle and naturally give rise to obstruction.
Although dependent origination has no master, opening the way is not of one accord.
This is the meaning.
Third, speaking from returning to the origin.
In contrast to the first meaning, the first meaning is general.
The second, in terms of delusion, only goes forth and does not return.
Now, this is only a return, because it returns to the original source, which is precisely the meaning of stillness.
Therefore, the Book of Changes says: Return, do we see the mind of Heaven and Earth in this?
However, what has gone must return. The Book of Changes says: There is no going without returning, this is the end of Heaven and Earth.
Within this single meaning, there is going and returning by oneself.
Therefore, in the Sutra of the Inconceivable Buddha Realm Spoken by Manjushri, the Good and Supreme Celestial Son asked Manjushri:
How does one cultivate the bodhisattva path?
Manjushri first spoke of the practice of going together, and then said:
Furthermore, Celestial Son!
Having going and having returning is called cultivating the bodhisattva path.
What is meant by having going and having returning?
Observing the desires in the minds of sentient beings is called going, and teaching the Dharma according to their capacities is called returning.
Entering samÄdhi is called going, causing sentient beings to attain samÄdhi is called returning.
Practicing the holy path oneself is called going, and being able to teach and transform all ordinary beings is called returning.
Thus, attaining the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas oneself is going, and causing sentient beings to attain the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas is returning.
Using skillful means to leave saá¹ƒsÄra oneself is going, and causing sentient beings to leave saá¹ƒsÄra is returning.
Taking pleasure in quiescence is going, and always remaining in saá¹ƒsÄra to teach and transform sentient beings is returning.
Diligent observation of one's own going and returning is going, and expounding this Dharma for the sake of sentient beings is returning.
Cultivating emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness oneself is going, and expounding the Dharma in order to cause sentient beings to eliminate the three kinds of conceptual thoughts is returning.
Firmly making vows is going, and according to one's vows, rescuing and delivering sentient beings is returning.
Arousing the bodhi mind and vowing to sit at the site of enlightenment is called going, and fully cultivating the practices of the bodhisattva is called returning.
This is the bodhisattva's path of going and returning.
The commentary states:
The first ten pairs, the upper sentence is self-benefit as going, going to nirvana;
The lower sentence is benefiting others as returning, returning to saá¹ƒsÄra to transform sentient beings.
Although there is going and returning, it is all for reversing back to the source and restoring the original mind.
Here, boundless also has two meanings:
First, the bodhisattva's ocean of practices is vast and numerous, boundless; second, each and every one accords with principle, profound and limitless.
However, the above three meanings are all the function of the dharma realm.
Second, motion and stillness are one source is the essence of the dharma realm.
Opposing the above three meanings in terms of delusion and enlightenment, motion is going, and stillness is returning.
Although there are two gates of movement and stillness, delusion and enlightenment, the true nature that is deluded is one source, not two. The non-dual source is precisely the essence.
Second, in the pair of only delusion, movement is going back and forth, because there is coming and going;
stillness is the emptiness of substance, because it is tranquil in dependence on each other.
If one does not abandon movement to seek stillness, one must seek stillness in all movements.
Since one must seek stillness in all movements, then although moving, one is always still.
Then, although the names of movement and stillness differ, their source is non-dual. The non-dual source is precisely the one essence.
Third, in the teaching of returning to the origin and reversing back to the basis, stillness is self-benefit, and movement is benefiting others.
The two benefits guide each other, transforming without transformation, thus not losing the one source, which is the essence of the Dharma realm.
If it is compared to the above two kinds of boundless, vastness is boundless, which is movement;
boundlessness is precisely boundlessness, which is stillness.
The unobstructed movement and stillness is the one source.
Boundlessness and boundlessness are tranquil in their intrinsic nature.
Third, containing myriad wonders with remainder refers to the magnitude of the characteristics of the Dharma realm.
It means that myriad wonders exist within the profound and mysterious.
The profound and mysterious pure Dharma realm is able to contain the subtle characteristics of the magnitude of the myriad virtues of nature, which are contained.
Characteristics depend on nature, and nature is all-encompassing, therefore it is called containing.

The essence of nature is without external, while the virtues of characteristics have names. The number of named cannot pervade the essence without external, therefore it is said to have remainder, then it is vast and still has remaining ground.
Therefore, the Asaá¹…khyeya Parivarta says: In a single subtle hair pore, innumerable lands enter in sequence.
The hair pore can contain those lands, but the lands cannot pervade the hair pore.
This is the meaning.
Using the hand to illustrate the nature, and using the lands to illustrate the indestructible characteristics, therefore the vast characteristics cannot pervade the small nature.
However, this magnitude of characteristics roughly has two meanings:
First, in terms of non-emptiness, it is endowed with the nature and merits of the Ganges sands. This is the meaning of the common teaching.
Second, in terms of the unobstructed interpenetration of all phenomena, the characteristics of the ten mysteries are inherently complete. This is the meaning of the distinct teaching.
However, the two characters myriad marvels also have the meaning of Laozi. The Daodejing says, The Dao that can be spoken of is not the constant Dao.
The name that can be named is not the constant name.
Before the existence of name, there was the beginning of Heaven and Earth. After the existence of name, there were the myriad creatures.
Always be desireless to observe its subtlety. Always have desire to observe its manifestations.
These two emerge from the same source but are given different names. They are both called the profound.
The profound within the profound is the gateway to the myriad marvels.
The commentary says:
However, their meaning takes the void and nothingness of nature to be the profound and marvelous. It further erases its traces, thus saying again profound.
This means being desireless within desirelessness, and myriad phenomena arise from this, thus saying the gateway to the myriad marvels.

Now, borrowing their words but not taking their meaning, the intention is to take the one true Dharma realm as the profound and wondrous essence, and the characteristics of the essence are the myriad wonders.
Fourth, transcending verbal thought and standing out dissolves and brushes away the above three.
When dissolved, the three and one mutually include each other; when brushed away, the three and one are both quiescent.
How is it transcended?
It means that principle is perfect while words are biased; when words give rise to principle, it is lost.
The Dharma has no conceptual thoughts; if one thinks, chaos arises.
Both are transcended, therefore it is said to stand out.
Therefore, Master ZHAO said:
When the mouth wants to speak, the words are lost; when the mind is about to contemplate, thoughts vanish.
Then it stands out beyond the realm of words and images.
Why is it so?ğŸ”½If one wants to speak of the characteristics and functions, they are the same as the quiescent essence;
if one wants to say the essence is quiescent, the characteristics and functions are in chaos.

It is one yet three, with different characteristics; it is three yet one, with no duality in essence. The three and one are unobstructed, mutually negating and both forgotten, with existence and annihilation nowhere to be found. How can words and images reach it?
Therefore, it is said to be far beyond.

Moreover, borrowing this forgetting and transcendence to dispel words and thoughts, neither existence nor non-existence can be relied upon. Therefore, the following sutra says, Although not relying on the path of words, one also does not become attached to the absence of words.

Moreover, the characteristics of words are originally still, and even forgetting is forgotten. This means that words and forgetting are mutually dependent and also still, so the term far beyond is used to wipe away the traces of words and forgetting.
Fifth, Only the Dharma realm can do this concludes the Dharma to which it belongs, which is the Dharma realm.
It means that it alone possesses the above virtues, and is exclusively in the Dharma realm.

As for the second explanation in terms of basis and branches, the first sentence in the above five sentences is the arising of the branches from the basis, which is the establishment of all dharmas without moving from the ultimate truth;
The next line includes the branches and returns to the root, which is not destroying provisional names while speaking of true suchness;
The third line is the unobstructedness of the root and branches, which is the distinctness of nature and characteristics;
The fourth line is the mutual quiescence of the root and branches, which is the absence of verbalization and conceptualization;
The last line concludes and belongs to the four meanings.
Third, clarifying the general categories of the Dharma realm has three main points:
First, in terms of the three Dharma realms.

The first line is the realm of phenomena, the next line is the realm of principle, the third line is the unobstructed Dharma realm, the fourth line integrates and sweeps away the above three, and the fifth line concludes and belongs to the above three Dharma realms.
Second, in terms of the four Dharma realms.
Going and returning without end is phenomena.
Motion and stillness are of one source, which includes the three meanings.
Motion is phenomena, stillness is principle, and motion and stillness being of one source is the unobstructed Dharma realm of phenomena and principle.
Containing myriad wonders and having surplus is the unobstructed Dharma realm of phenomena and phenomena.
Transcending words and thoughts, it completely merges the four dharma realms.
It is only the dharma realm, and it is also connected to the four dharma realms.
Third, it is connected to the five dharma realms.
Going and returning, and movement, are all conditioned.
Stillness is unconditioned. The one source has two aspects:
If they mutually negate and both cease, it becomes the dharma realm of neither conditioned nor unconditioned;
If they mutually merge and both illuminate, it becomes the dharma realm of both conditioned and unconditioned.
Containing myriad wonders with remainder, it is the unobstructed dharma realm.
Transcending words and thoughts, it completely merges the five dharma realms.
It is only the dharma realm, and it is connected to the five dharma realms.
Fourth, the overall intention of establishing [the treatise] is as follows. The reason for initially discussing the dharma realm is that there should be a question:

Many commentaries and sub-commentaries first discuss how the TathÄgata responds to beings by first manifesting in the lesser vehicle and then the greater vehicle, or by not appearing and then appearing, or by not speaking and then speaking.
Why then does it first narrate the Dharma realm?
Therefore, the answer now is:

Because it is the fundamental purport of this sÅ«tra, because it is the universal essence of all sÅ«tras, because it is the universal basis of all dharmas, because it is the basis of the delusion and enlightenment of all sentient beings, because it is the ultimate realization of all Buddhas, because the practices of all Bodhisattvas arise from it, because it was expounded all at once from the beginning, and because it is different from other sÅ«tras that have gradual sequences.
However, the last intention directly answers the first question, and the previous intentions together form the last intention.

The second, dividing the profound and subtle, illuminating the mind and realm, praises the ability to expound the meaning, clarifying that this sÅ«tra expounds the Dharma realm, and therefore is difficult to conceive.
The text has seven sentences, which are divided into four parts:

The first two sentences generally clarify the ability to expound, the next two sentences specifically reveal the profundity and vastness, the next two sentences conclude the praise of the profundity and vastness, and the last sentence concludes the Dharma to which it belongs.
Now, the first.
As for the profound and subtle words, they refer to the many meanings of the Dharma realm mentioned above.
It means that the profound and subtle principles are analyzed and divided in this sutra.
It means that in the unobstructed Dharma realm, it is divided into the two aspects of mind and object, so the next line says illuminating the mind and object.
How is it analyzed?

It means that the true Dharma realm originally has no inside or outside, does not belong to one or many. The Buddha himself realized it to the end and knew that all beings have it equally. He wanted to make beings awaken to it, so he divided it into mind and object.
The object is what is realized, and the mind is what realizes it. Therefore, the next line quotes Master Yu's statement:
The mind is what the buddhas realize as the Dharma body, and the object is what the buddhas realize as the pure land.
Then both are what is realized, and wisdom is what realizes it.
The realized object is the vast and extensive, and the realizing mind is the buddha and the adornments.
It is explained extensively in the text, so it says analyzed.
As for illuminating and vastening the mind and realm, the mind and realm refer to what was opened above, and illuminating and vastening is precisely this sutra.
Illuminating means bright and illuminating.
Vastening means empty and expanding the small to make it large.
How does it illuminate the mind and realm?
It means that in this sutra, the mind that can observe and the realm that is observed, whether ordinary or sagely, causal or fruitional, are all completely included.
As the chapter on appearance explains the Buddha's realm, it is precisely the Buddha's realm.
Explaining the Tathagata's mind is precisely the Buddha's mind.
The mind and realm of all stages can be understood by analogy.
How does it illuminate the mind and realm?

It means that in this sutra, it teaches people to observe the mind and realm, as it says, If you want to know the Buddha's mind, you should observe the Buddha's wisdom. The Buddha's wisdom is without support, like space, which has no support.
This is to make one observe the Buddha's mind.
How does it make the mind and realm empty and vast?
As in the verse The nature of dharmas is originally empty and tranquil, without grasping and also without views.
The emptiness of nature is precisely the Buddha, inconceivable.
This is the empty mind and objects.
Without grasping is without objects, without views is without mind.

It also says If there are those who wish to know the Buddha's realm, they should purify their minds like empty space, far remove false thoughts and all grasping, and make the mind unobstructed in all directions.
This is also the empty mind and objects.

It also says If there are those who wish to attain the TathÄgata's wisdom, they should depart from all false discrimination, and penetrate through existence and nonexistence to be equal, and quickly become a great guide for humans and gods.
This is also the meaning of the empty mind and objects.
How does one expand the small to make it great?

It means that if one expands the mind, there are no objects outside the mind, and if one expands the objects, there is no mind outside the objects. Because by simply bringing up one of them, all dharmas are included without exception, and are thus boundless.
Therefore, a sutra below says, There is no suchness outside of cognition for cognition to enter, nor is there cognition outside of suchness that can realize suchness.
The upper sentence expands the mind, and the lower sentence expands the realm.
The true mind and true realm are originally boundless. If delusion is the same as truth, then the small is expanded to be great.
The sutra says, The profound realm of the Tathagata is equal in measure to empty space.
The Buddha's realm is great.
It also says, The Buddha's wisdom is vast and equal to empty space, and the true mind is great.
Knowing that delusion is originally true, seeing the Buddha is pure.
As the mind, so is the Buddha; as the Buddha, so are sentient beings.
The mind, the Buddha, and sentient beings, these three are no different.
All expand the deluded mind, which is boundless.
The myriad dharmas of cause and effect are universally included in the mind and realm. Each and every thing can be expanded.
The commentary says, Exhausting principle and nature, penetrating the fruition and encompassing the cause - these two have two sentences, specifically praising the profundity and vastness.
Li means principle, and dao means the broad way.
Xing refers to the nature of dharmas, and xin refers to the profound nature of the mind.
If one exhausts the principle, then one reaches the nature.
In this sutra, the meaning and nature are both thoroughly investigated.
This borrows the words from the Explanation of the Gua in the Book of Changes.
It says, Exhausting principle and exhausting nature to reach life.
In the past, when the sages created the Book of Changes, they wanted to follow the principle of life and nature.
The commentary says, Life is the ultimate of birth. Exhausting principle is exhausting its ultimate.
It uses the character ultimate to explain nature, which is the ultimate.
If one exhausts the principle and nature, then one follows the mandate of heaven, so the next line says to follow the principle of life and nature.
Now I borrow the words and use them, but the meaning is different.
As for penetrating the fruit and encompassing the cause, it includes both profundity and vastness.

If it thoroughly investigates the fruition of the five periods and encompasses the causes of the six stages, then it is extensive. Therefore, the extensive explanation of the stages, causes, and effects cannot surpass this sÅ«tra.
If it is said that the causes pervade the ocean of fruition and the fruition penetrates the source of causes, and the two mutually penetrate each other, then it reveals the profundity.
When one first gives rise to the mind of enlightenment, one immediately achieves perfect enlightenment. This is the causes pervading the fruition.
Although one attains the way of the Buddha, one does not abandon the gateway of causes. This is the fruition penetrating the causes.
The above is based on the meaning of extensiveness.
Penetrating the fruition belongs to the fruition, and encompassing the causes belongs to the causes. This clarifies that the expounding teaching encompasses and penetrates those causes and effects.
Now, based on the profound explanation, penetrating the fruition belongs to the causes, because the causes penetrate that fruition;
encompassing the causes belongs to the fruition, because the fruition penetrates that cause.
This is the self-nature of cause and effect, and the encompassing and penetrating only belongs to what is expounded.
However, the expounding possesses the clarification of this meaning.
Moreover, the causes pervading the ocean of fruition and the fruition penetrating the source of causes are the words of the ancients.
Now, I wish to fully contain the meaning of profound and vast, saying it penetrates the effect and encompasses the cause.
The commentary says vast and profound, broad and great, all complete. The first three sentences and two phrases conclude the praise of the profound and vast.
The first sentence clarifies the appearance of the profound and vast, the second sentence reveals the reason for the profound and vast.
Vast is the appearance of depth.
Profound is the appearance of breadth.
Profound also means deep, also means middle, also called harmonious.
Therefore, Laozi says: The Way is profound and used, sometimes it seems not full.
Profound means profound and pervasive, also means deep and vast.
Therefore, Master ZHI said:
Vast and profound, what is not attained through it?
In the Sutra of the Eight Teachers, the Brahman Juna said:
I have heard that the meaning of the Buddha's Way is vast and profound, vast and boundless, nothing is not accomplished, no one is not liberated, and so on, which is the meaning of profound and vast.
It is also like the harmonious qi that gives birth to myriad things without being full, and harmonizes myriad dharmas to make them unobstructed.
As for vast and complete, this explains the reason for its profundity and vastness, because it is not lacking in anything.

This phrase also comes from the Appended Phrases of the Book of Changes, which says, The Book of Changes is vast and complete, with the Way of Heaven, the Way of Humans, and the Way of Earth. It combines the Three Powers and divides them into six.
The six are nothing else but the Way of the Three Powers.
Now, if we take the meaning and apply it to the sutra, it can also be likened to the three worlds:
The Way of Heaven is the correct enlightenment of wisdom;
The Way of Humans is sentient beings;
The Way of Earth is the world of vessels.
This sutra extensively explains the three worlds.
It can also be said that the Way of Heaven is the profound principle;
The Way of Earth is the phenomena;
The Way of Humans is the practitioners, the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas.
Although it is matched with this, the original intention is only to take in and include.
It means, within this fundamental Dharma wheel, what Dharma is not complete?
There is not a single matter or principle that is not ultimate, not a single cause or effect that is not complete.
The five periods and five flavors of cause and effect clearly manifest the fifty-two stages;
The profound text of the nine assemblies can be seen in the inconceivable ocean of teachings.
If one speaks of true and false, then the ordinary and the holy are clearly interpenetrating; if one speaks of the Dharma realm, then phenomena and principles are mutually inclusive.
In the Lotus Sutra, a single verse on the Buddha's knowledge and insight must be fully revealed.

This is called emptying the ocean of the Buddha's wisdom and exhausting the vast source of nature and characteristics. Therefore, it is said to be vast and complete.
The commentary states only the Flower Ornament Sutra of the Great Expansive Buddha is the fourth, concluding which Dharma it belongs to.
The above excellent matters are only in our Flower Ornament Sutra.
Third, below therefore our World-Honored One, it explains the inconceivable host.
The text has six sentences, the meaning is divided into four:

The first two sentences summarize the fulfillment of the fruit, the second one sentence speaks of the profound cause, the third one sentence clarifies the mysterious essence, and the fourth two sentences show the complete virtues.

The first says therefore our World-Honored One's ten bodies are first fulfilled is a general statement of the ten bodies, encompassing the following two sections, and clearly shows the inconceivability.
Because these ten bodies are unobstructed, the Buddha's teachings are not the three bodies.

As for saying therefore our, it is because the above expounder and the profound and wondrous vastness serve as the basis for all teachings, therefore our World-Honored One, having just attained perfect enlightenment, suddenly expounded this sutra.
As for the ten bodies, they will be listed below.
As for first fulfilled, when attaining perfect enlightenment, the bodies are just fulfilled.

Therefore, the sutra says, At that time, the World-Honored One, dwelling in this seat, attained perfect enlightenment with regard to all dharmas. His wisdom entered the three times, all equally. His body filled all worlds. His voice universally harmonized with the lands of the ten directions. This is the first fulfillment.
Just attaining enlightenment refers to the body of bodhi, because this is the general [aspect].

The initially enlightened one is the same as the originally enlightened one, and there is no longer a distinction between the initial and original. Therefore, it is called just attaining. It will be extensively explained below.
The commentary states, Relying on the practice of vows to pervade, which is one sentence, speaking of the profundity of the cause.
There are two kinds of relying on the cause:
First, relying on the cause of vows. The sutra says, The power of vows of Vairocana Buddha pervades the Dharma realm.
Second, relying on the cause of practice. The verse of the main mountain deity says, The superior practices cultivated in the past are boundless.
Relying on the cause of vows, pervading the function of the fruition, this is the vow-body.

As for the term pervading, it means to completely encompass, and also comes from the Book of Changes, the Appended Phrases says, The Changes are in accord with Heaven and Earth, and therefore can pervade the Way of Heaven and Earth.
The commentary says:

Since the sage has created the Changes in accord with Heaven and Earth, what is spoken of in the Changes is the same as the principles of Heaven and Earth, and therefore can pervade the Way of Heaven and Earth. This is used to illustrate that the TathÄgata's original vow and practice intends to universally benefit beings. Now, because he has attained the power of his vow and practice,
he pervades the Dharma realm, which is called pervading.
The commentary says, Blending empty space as its essence - this one sentence clarifies the profundity of the essence.
However, there are two meanings:
First, in terms of the World-Honored One himself possessing the ten bodies, this is the Dharma body.
Because the Dharma-nature body is taken as the Dharma body, therefore the sutra below says, The emptiness of nature is precisely the Buddha, inconceivable.
It also says, The Buddha takes the Dharma as his body, pure like empty space.

Second, in terms of external empty space, it melts the three worlds to form the Buddha's body. Then external empty space is the body of empty space, so it is said, Blending empty space as the essence, the nature is unobstructed and interpenetrating.
The commentary says, Rich with myriad virtues, empty of even a trace of dust. There are four lines with two sentences, showing the completeness of virtues.
The upper line is the completeness of virtues, the lower line is the quiescence of all hindrances.
Myriad is the great number of general characteristics.

In reality, it is endowed with inexhaustible virtues, so the following sutra says, The number of dust motes in a buddha-land can be counted, the water in the great ocean can be drunk up, empty space can be measured, and the wind can be bound, but no one can fully describe the Buddha's merits.
The inexhaustible virtues are collectively called myriad virtues.
The dust-like ignorance, seeds, manifestations, and habitual tendencies are all completely eliminated, so it is said, Empty of even a trace of dust.
In general, there are two kinds of hindrances, and these hindrances have three aspects:
First, the active state; second, the seeds; third, the habitual tendencies.
The habitual tendencies are subtle, likened to a fine dust particle.
Even the most subtle aspect does not exist, let alone the other more coarse aspects.
If we generally match these with the three virtues, the myriad virtues are contained within wisdom and kindness.
The next line is precisely the virtue of cessation.
